author: By Carl Hulse
title: When Debuts Flop: Katie Britt Is the Latest in a Long Line of Botched Opening Acts
description: The Republican senator, whose State of the Union response drew savage criticism, is not the first novice lawmaker from the South to see her introductory event veer off the rails.
content: Senator Katie Britt, Republican of Alabama, had not finished delivering her breathless, overly dramatized and fact-challenged response to President Biden’s State of the Union address last week when the ridicule and criticism began pouring in from Republicans and Democrats alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Williams, Natasha Dailey, Campbell Robertson and Orlando Mayorquín
title: Three Killed and Several Injured After Reports of Tornadoes in the Midwest
description: A storm ripped through a mobile home community in eastern Indiana. Tornadoes were also reported in Ohio and Kentucky.
content: At least three people were killed and dozens were injured after a parade of severe weather marched through Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio overnight, spinning off at least six devastating tornadoes, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Kent Campbell, Pivotal Figure in the Fight Against Malaria, Dies at 80
description: Among his accomplishments in a four-decade career in public health, he helped pioneer programs providing bed nets in Africa.
content: Kent Campbell, an instrumental figure in the global battle against malaria — most notably in Africa, where he led an innovative program providing bed nets to protect rural villagers from the mosquitoes carrying the disease — died on Feb. 20 in Oro Valley, Ariz., a suburb of Tucson. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Judge Delays Trump’s Manhattan Trial Until at Least Mid-April
description: The judge scheduled a hearing for March 25, the day the trial had been scheduled to begin, to consider Donald J. Trump’s request to further delay or dismiss the case.
content: A New York judge on Friday delayed Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan until at least mid-April, postponing the only one of Mr. Trump’s four criminal cases that appeared set to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Miami Beach, Seeking Quieter Spring Break, Sets Curfew
description: Revelers will be barred from staying out past midnight each night this weekend. In the weeks leading up to peak spring break season, city officials had warned that a curfew was likely.
content: Escalating its aggressive push for a quieter spring break, Miami Beach declared a three-night curfew beginning on Friday, citing the large crowds it expects over what has usually been the peak weekend of the season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Anushka Patil
title: Another Gaza Aid Convoy Ends in Violence, With at Least 20 Killed
description: The Gaza Health Ministry accused Israel of a “targeted” attack. Israel’s military denied the accusation, blaming Palestinian gunmen for the violence.
content: For at least the second time in just over two weeks, a convoy bringing aid to hunger-stricken northern Gaza ended in bloodshed late Thursday when Palestinians were killed and wounded in an attack surrounding the trucks, according to Gazan health officials and the Israeli military, which offered divergent accounts of what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: There’s an Art to Arranging a Bookshelf. Here’s How It’s Done.
description: Jeremiah Brent, the newest cast member of Netflix’s “Queer Eye,” shows how he styles the shelves in the home he shares with his husband, Nate Berkus.
content: In a public library, styling a bookshelf is easy: Just fill it with books. At home, a bookcase needs to do a lot more than hold books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Make Guinness Beef Stew on Saturday for Sunday
description: That way the flavors have time to deepen in the fridge, with plenty of celery root, carrots and parsnips, and lemon juice to make it pop.
content: Good morning. How are you doing? This week marks four years since many of us went into lockdown after the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus to be a pandemic. Amid the fear and illness there would turn out to be, for some, scant pleasures: fragrant, crusty sourdough boules, long walks on quiet streets, seeking beauty amid the darkness. But for many there was simply dread, dread unending, and only pantry meals to mark the passage of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Authors Withdraw From PEN World Voices Festival Over Its Response to Gaza War
description: More than a dozen authors, including Lorrie Moore, Naomi Klein, Michelle Alexander, Hisham Matar and Isabella Hammad, have signed a protest letter that announced their withdrawal.
content: A group of prominent authors announced that they have withdrawn from this year’s PEN World Voices Festival over what they described as PEN America’s inadequate response to the war and humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Here’s How the Decision in the Trump Case Could Be Appealed
description: The defendants could ask the judge to go straight to an appeals court before trial, delaying the prosecution of the former president and his allies.
content: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump and his co-defendants in Georgia could appeal a judge’s decision allowing Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, to remain on the election interference case. But it will be up to the judge whether their appeal could go forward right away, or if it would have to wait until after a trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Deadly Foosball, Nefarious Pool Guys and the Loony Musings of ‘Valley Heat’
description: Christian Duguay’s podcast purports to be about the neighbors in the Rancho Equestrian District of Burbank. One thing is for sure: It’s masterfully absurd.
content: In the Rancho Equestrian District of Burbank, Calif., they take foosball seriously — and those who don’t, well, they might get their thumbs broken. Or worse. Foosball is life or death there, but mostly death, or at least it can seem that way on “Valley Heat,” a deliriously deadpan fictional podcast about this real neighborhood that delights in ludicrous lore and nonsense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Where’s the Next Generation of Great Coaches?
description: A trip back to 2004 suggests even sure things can sometimes be a gamble.
content: Twenty years, it would appear, is a very long time indeed. This week, a brief video montage fluttered through the flotsam and jetsam that clog my (and your) social media feeds — the engagement-farming banalities, the craven attention-seekers, the willfully deranged Kate Middleton theories — to celebrate the glorious madness of 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Truck Driver Charged Over Role in Deadly ‘Super Fog’ Pileup in Louisiana
description: Seven people were killed. The driver, Ronald Britt, is charged with negligent homicide in a crash that killed one of them.
content: A truck driver faces charges including negligent homicide related to his role in a highway crash during a dense “super fog” in Louisiana in October that caused a huge traffic pileup and left seven people dead and dozens injured, the authorities said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
title: Biden Embraces Schumer’s Speech Castigating Netanyahu
description: President Biden did not explicitly endorse any of the specific criticisms in the speech. But his comments were the latest step in his escalating public critique of the Israeli prime minister.
content: President Biden on Friday praised Senator Chuck Schumer’s address lashing out at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, calling it “a good speech” that raised concerns “shared not only by him but by many Americans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Klein
title: What the Fight Over the Capital One-Discover Merger Misses About Our Terrible Credit Card System
description: The deal will do nothing to fix policies that exacerbate the wealth gap and help big business get even bigger.
content: A fight has commenced over Capital One’s effort to acquire Discover, a deal that would birth an enormous credit card company rivaling Visa, Mastercard and American Express. The resulting competition could, in the short run, lower some costs to businesses and consumers. However, over the longer term, the merger would keep intact the broken and predatory system in which credit card companies profit handsomely by rewarding our richest Americans and advantaging the biggest corporations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Man Who Shot Another on Subway Train Unlikely to Be Charged, D.A. Says
description: Evidence indicates that a 32-year-old man acted in self-defense when he shot a man with whom he had been fighting on a moving A train, Brooklyn’s top prosecutor said.
content: A 32-year-old man who took a gun from a second man and shot him in the head during an altercation on a moving A train Thursday evening appears to have acted in self-defense and will not be criminally charged for now, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: Making a Scene on the Radio
description: In an era of podcasts and influencers, Montez Press Radio is reviving the D.I.Y. spirit of a bygone downtown New York City.
content: “Do you think about your organs, Timmy?” asked Moriah Evans, an experimental choreographer. “How often do you commit yourself to trying to sense the bodies within your body?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Talking ‘Dune’: Book and Movies
description: The Times’s critic Alissa Wilkinson discusses Frank Herbert’s classic science fiction novel and Denis Villeneuve’s film adaptations.
content: Frank Herbert’s epic novel “Dune” and its successors have been entrenched in the science fiction and fantasy canon for almost six decades, a rite of passage for proudly nerdy readers across the generations. But “Dune” is experiencing a broader cultural resurgence at the moment thanks to Denis Villeneuve’s recent film adaptations starring Timothée Chalamet. (Part 2 is in theaters now.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Slithering, Hissing Business That’s Booming
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 15, 2024.
content: “It’s one of those jobs that can take a toll.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Watershed Moment for the Politics of Israel, Courtesy of Chuck Schumer
description: Republicans have long sought to make Israel a partisan issue, framing their party as the only one truly supportive of the Jewish state. The Senate majority leader’s blistering speech may have helped.
content: Over 44 painstakingly scripted minutes on the floor of the Senate on Thursday, the majority leader, Chuck Schumer, spoke of his Jewish identity, his love for the State of Israel, his horror at the wanton slaughter of Israelis on Oct. 7 and his views on the apportionment of blame for the carnage in Gaza, saying that it first and foremost lay with the terrorists of Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 15, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 15, 2024.
content: An article on Tuesday about automakers that are sharing consumers’ driving behavior with insurance companies referred imprecisely to Honda’s disclosure of its relationship with Verisk, a data broker. That relationship is described in an FAQ on Honda’s website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Justin Timberlake Looks Back but Does Not Reckon
description: On “Everything I Thought It Was,” his sixth solo album, this artist feigns new vulnerability but relies on old tricks and his ’N Sync bandmates.
content: Shortly before writing the song that would become his first single in six years, Justin Timberlake worked with his musical director Adam Blackstone on an arrangement of John Lennon’s “Jealous Guy,” in the style of Donny Hathaway’s famous cover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Sets Rules for Blocking Citizens From Officials’ Accounts
description: In two unanimous rulings, the justices tried to distinguish between private conduct, which is not subject to the First Amendment, and state action, which is.
content: The Supreme Court, in a pair of unanimous decisions on Friday, added some clarity to a vexing constitutional puzzle: how to decide when elected officials violate the First Amendment by blocking people from their social media accounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Why Is Congress Investigating a Union for Being Anti-Israel?
description: Republicans issue a subpoena over a resolution condemning the Gaza war.
content: Like many progressive organizations, the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys, a union that represents public defenders in the New York City area, has been convulsed by battles over Israel’s war in Gaza. A recent article in the right-leaning Free Press revealed the strident and sometimes ugly language that union members used during a fight over a resolution, passed in December, condemning Israel’s actions and supporting a boycott of the country. In messages from a group chat, defenders of Israel were called “fascists” and, in one case, “mentally disturbed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Don’t Think of It as a Contest Between Biden and Trump
description: What matters even more than the candidates is the coalitions they lead.
content: It’s official — we have a rematch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: If Nvidia Keeps Rising Like This, It Will Be Bigger Than the Global Economy
description: A.I. fervor has rocketed the chip company’s share price upward. Our columnist asked A.I. chatbots how big Nvidia would become if it kept growing as fast as it had over the past year.
content: It’s not a household name quite yet, but anyone who follows the stock market knows at least a little about Nvidia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and Sydney Ember
title: Boeing Directs Airlines to Check Cockpit Seats on 787s After Latam Incident
description: The sudden plunge of a Latam Airlines 787 Dreamliner this week might have been caused by a flight attendant hitting a switch on a cockpit seat.
content: Boeing has told airlines to check the cockpit seats of its 787 Dreamliner plane, the company said on Friday, after a Latam Airlines plane suddenly plunged on a flight to Auckland, New Zealand, on Monday, injuring passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Dressing the Part of Barbara Walters
description: Women in media recently had a chance to browse and buy clothes owned by the trailblazing TV news anchor.
content: If anyone could make a baby pink suit look intimidating, it was Barbara Walters. The TV news anchor coolly lobbed questions at the Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in a 1989 interview while sheathed shoulder to knee in pastel Chanel and pearls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: An American Who Has Helped Clear 815,000 Bombs From Vietnam
description: Chuck Searcy has spent decades of his life redressing a deadly legacy of America’s war in Vietnam: unexploded ordnance.
content: On a visit to the former battlefield of Khe Sanh, scene of one of the bloodiest standoffs of the Vietnam War, the only people Chuck Searcy encountered on the broad, barren field were two young boys who led him to an unexploded rocket lying by a ditch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Marris
title: New York Is Wilder Than You Think
description: The city is a flourishing ecosystem of untamed creatures.
content: New York is about to get really wild. Every spring, millions of birds fly from South and Central America along the Atlantic Flyway, heading for northern breeding grounds. Many of them choose to fly through New York City, sometimes stopping to rest in Central Park. You can take the subway to 81st Street, stroll across the way and maybe see a maraschino-cherry-red male scarlet tanager with black wings, fresh from the foothills of the Andes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Stays Out of Dispute Over Drag Show at Texas University
description: An L.G.B.T.Q. student group had asked the justices to intercede, saying the performance was protected by the First Amendment.
content: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected a request from an L.G.B.T.Q. student group at a public university in Texas to let it put on a drag show on campus over the objections of the university’s president, who had refused to allow it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Schumer’s Critique of Netanyahu Reveals a Growing Gap, Analysts Say
description: Many Israelis support the Senate majority leader’s call for early elections, but even Netanyahu’s rivals were reluctant to seize on the criticism while the country is focused on the war in Gaza.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer’s harsh critique of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his government revealed the widening gap between Israel and its most important ally, the United States, analysts said on Friday, but was unlikely to prompt Israel’s government to chart a new course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Climate Protesters Disrupt Broadway Play Starring Jeremy Strong
description: A performance of a new production of Ibsen’s “An Enemy of the People” was interrupted by protesters who shouted “no theater on a dead planet.”
content: A trio of climate change protesters disrupted a performance of “An Enemy of the People,” starring Jeremy Strong, on Broadway Thursday night, shouting “no theater on a dead planet” as they were escorted out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: advocate
description: This word has appeared in 879 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word advocate has appeared in 879 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 26 in “They Promoted Body Positivity. Then They Lost Weight” by Katie J. M. Baker:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
title: Data Dump Exposes the Fuzzy Lines Between Money and Politics in India
description: Lists of donors and beneficiaries cast government contracts and police investigations in an unflattering new light.
content: Politics in India is an expensive business, and sometimes lucrative, too. In this year’s election, parties are expected to spend more than $14 billion — as much as in the United States. But there has been little in the way of transparency for the huge sums sloshing around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Anthony Boyle Is Moving Forward by Looking Backward
description: The actor has broken out on TV this year in the historical series “Masters of the Air” and “Manhunt.”
content: Anthony Boyle was out of luck. He had been expelled from his Catholic boys school for “behavioral problems.” He had also been fired from his job at a nightclub after getting caught drinking while working.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Main
title: A Seal’s Spray Adds a Chapter to the Science of Spitting
description: The observation suggests that seals join cobras, archerfish and other animals known to spit, although researchers can only speculate about the reason for the mammal’s expectoration.
content: On Jan. 3, 2022, Clare Jacobs, a bird-watcher, was delighted to spot a rare white-tailed eagle, or Haliaeetus albicilla, at a nature reserve on the Isle of Wight in southern England. These birds, also known as sea eagles or ernes, vanished from the region some 250 years ago, but more than two dozen birds have been released on the island since 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Connecticut State Trooper Is Acquitted in Killing of a Black Teenager
description: Brian North faced up to 40 years in prison for firing seven times at Mubarak Soulemane after a car chase.
content: A former Connecticut state trooper was acquitted on Friday of manslaughter and other charges in the fatal shooting of a 19-year-old Black man after a car chase four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: The Zombies of the U.S. Tax Code: Why Fossil Fuels Subsidies Seem Impossible to Kill
description: For the fourth year in a row, President Biden is trying to eliminate federal tax breaks for coal, oil and gas companies. But fossil fuel subsidies have proven difficult to stop.
content: SHINGTON — As a candidate in 2020, Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigned to end billions of dollars in annual tax breaks to oil and gas companies within his first year in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Ewing
title: After a Breakup, A Bipartisan Union
description: Jared Jones and Caroline Darmody’s political differences contributed to a split. Eventually they were able to appreciate all they had in common.
content: Caroline Marie Darmody first noticed Jared Joseph Jones during a February 2016 orientation session for an upcoming staff delegation trip to India. At the time, both worked as legislative assistants in Washington, but on different sides of the aisle: Mr. Jones for Republican Senator Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia and Ms. Darmody for Democratic Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III of Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: New R.N.C. Chair Declares ‘a United Front’ With Trump After Sweeping Changes
description: Michael Whatley, an ally of Donald J. Trump who took over the Republican National Committee last week, celebrated a series of major changes in a memo on Thursday.
content: Michael Whatley, an ally of Donald J. Trump who took over the Republican National Committee last week, celebrated a series of major changes at the committee in a memo on Thursday and declared that the party would be “a united operation, and a united front” with Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: ‘Squid Game’ Actor Found Guilty of Sexual Misconduct
description: Oh Young-soo, who portrayed a contestant in the Netflix drama, was given a suspended sentence. He was found guilty of indecent assault.
content: A South Korean court on Friday convicted Oh Young-soo, an actor who won a Golden Globe for his portrayal of a contestant in the Netflix survival drama “Squid Game,” of indecent assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke and Yael Malka For The New York Times
title: Irish Dance for All Levels, All Bodies, All Genders
description: Gayli, a dance night at a Brooklyn bar, provides a welcoming atmosphere for Irish dancing.
content: Under the multicolored lights of a Brooklyn pub on a recent Monday night, a small crowd skipped and swung in circles, scrambling to keep up with the tempo of an Irish reel. Some were seasoned professionals; others were dipping a toe into Irish social dancing for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Without Senators in Sight, Christine Blasey Ford Retells Her Story
description: Her lucid memoir, “One Way Back,” describes life before, during and after she testified that Brett Kavanaugh had sexually assaulted her in high school.
content: “Indelible in the hippocampus is the laughter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Soho House Seeks to Knock Back Its Critics
description: The members club operator disclosed improving financial results as it faces criticism from a short seller and weighs going private again.
content: Since going public nearly two years ago, the members club chain Soho House has endured a sharp decline in its stock price, economic turmoil and a short seller’s declaring that its shares are worthless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Are You Tired of Influencers?
description: Do you trust the product recommendations you see on social media? Or are you increasingly skeptical of people trying to sell you stuff online?
content: Are influencers all over your social media feed? How do you feel when you come across videos or photos of product recommendations, “hauls” and “unboxings,” or when creators direct you to their TikTok shops and Amazon storefronts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean, Elian Peltier and Mady Camara
title: Senegal’s Leading Opposition Politicians Freed From Jail Just Before Election
description: The presidential candidate of the main opposition party, as well as its powerful founder, was released 10 days before the West African country is set to hold a national election.
content: Two opposition party politicians were released from jail in Senegal on Thursday night, just 10 days before a nationwide election in which one of them is running for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Isn’t Shocked to See Trump Back in Court
description: ”What’s still a mystery is why a bunch of top secret documents were taken by a president who, by all accounts, does not read,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read Nathan Wade’s Resignation and Fani Willis’s Response
description: Mr. Wade’s resignation paves the way for Ms. Willis to keep pursuing the Georgia election case against Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Zucker
title: First Came Family. Then Came Marriage (to a Grandmother’s Relief).
description: Twelve years ago, Melanie White sold Drew Trotter nine pairs of jeans. She also won his heart.
content: Mary Morton, a 99-year-old retired assistant principal in the Bronx, N.Y., wanted to live long enough to watch Melanie Renee White, her granddaughter, walk down the aisle with her then longtime boyfriend, Andrew R. Trotter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: Once You Watch an Ernie Gehr Film, You’ll Never See the World the Same Way
description: A MoMA series shows how the artist pushes the boundaries of cinema in short movies that both delight and baffle.
content: Movies have been around for well over a century, and for roughly half that time, the American filmmaker Ernie Gehr has — playfully, thoughtfully, beautifully — shown us just how far out, exciting and liberating they can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: White House Calls on Republicans to End Biden Impeachment Inquiry
description: The president’s counsel told Speaker Mike Johnson that it was “obviously time to move on,” citing G.O.P. lawmakers’ own doubts about the impeachment bid.
content: The White House insisted on Friday that House Republicans end their effort to impeach President Biden, declaring that “enough is enough” after their monthslong inquiry failed to turn up promised evidence of high crimes and misdemeanors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: ‘The Regime’ and the Dictators I Have Known
description: The HBO show is set in a fictional European country, but The Times’s chief diplomatic correspondent recognizes references to many real despots and failed states.
content: “The Regime,” the oddball limited series from HBO, is like a teenager’s dream of dictatorship. In the lengthy and sometimes ponderous tale of an unnamed country in “Middle Europe,” there are various references, more literary than lived, to the top authoritarian hits of the last 50 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Working in Old Age Can’t Be the Only Answer to the Retirement Crisis
description: Longer lives mean longer careers, right? It’s not so simple.
content: Teresa Ghilarducci, a labor economist, begins her new book with a story about an 82-year-old cashier at Walmart who was able to retire — finally — after a customer started a GoFundMe campaign for him that blew up on social media. “Is this what America’s retirement system has come to?” she asks. “Are we heading for a TikTok pension system?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Pence Says He Won’t Endorse Trump, but Won’t Vote for Biden Either
description: The vice president under Donald J. Trump said the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol was not the sole factor in his decision.
content: Mike Pence, Donald J. Trump’s vice president, indicated on Friday that he would not fall into line behind the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, as some of Mr. Trump’s other previous rivals, including Ron DeSantis, Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott, have done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Families Are Moved From Shelter Where Police Fired Stun Gun at Migrant
description: Several families, including that of the man who recorded a video of officers using a stun gun on a migrant holding a toddler, were transferred to other shelters with little explanation.
content: A few days after a violent altercation in which the police struck and used a stun gun on a Venezuelan migrant at a city-run shelter in Queens, that man’s family and three other families staying at the shelter received unexpected news with little explanation: They had to move out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost, John Yoon and Isabella Kwai
title: McDonald’s Apologizes for ‘Global Technology Outage’ That Hit Japan, Australia and Elsewhere
description: Customers had problems ordering at restaurants in several countries on Friday. Restaurants in Japan closed, while some in Australia reportedly reverted to using pen and paper.
content: McDonald’s customers in Australia, Japan and Hong Kong reported having trouble ordering at the fast-food restaurants on Friday, leading some restaurants to suspend online ordering and others to close entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik
title: Russia Strengthens Its Internet Controls in Critical Year for Putin
description: Facing an election this weekend and the fallout from Aleksei Navalny’s death and the war in Ukraine, Russia has intensified online censorship using techniques pioneered by China.
content: Russia is ratcheting up its internet censorship ahead of elections this weekend that are all but assured to give President Vladimir V. Putin another six years in power, further shrinking one of the last remaining spaces for political activism, independent information and free speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Bernie Sanders Proposes Reducing Americans’ Workweek to 32 Hours
description: His proposal would pare down the workweek over a four-year period. The 40-hour workweek has stood as the standard in the U.S. since it became enshrined in federal law in 1940.
content: Senator Bernie Sanders this week unveiled legislation to reduce the standard workweek in the United States from 40 hours to 32, without a reduction in pay, saying Americans are working longer hours for less pay despite advances in technology and productivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: Down the Rabbit Hole in Search of a Few Frames of Irish American History
description: The silent film “The Callahans and the Murphys” was pulled after an uproar over stereotyping. What happened next tantalized one fan of old movies.
content: One moment I am sprawled on a couch in my New Jersey home, lost in another classic old movie. The next, I am falling through the floorboards and tumbling like Alice into the wondrous unknown, only to land in a bunkerlike government structure built into the side of a Virginia mountain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Highlights of the Judge’s Decision in the Georgia Trump Case
description: The district attorney, Fani T. Willis, was given two choices: have her ex-boyfriend withdraw from the prosecution team or step aside herself.
content: A judge overseeing the criminal election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump in Georgia declined on Friday to disqualify the district attorney leading the prosecution, Fani T. Willis, over a romantic relationship she had with the lawyer she hired to manage the case, Nathan J. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nell Gallogly
title: Young Entrepreneurs Find a Way to Indulge Their C.E.O. Dreams
description: Fresh business school graduates are raising “search funds” from willing investors to buy companies they can lead.
content: Edward Silva grew up wanting to be a chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bergin
title: Pets or Pests? How Australia Tackles its Two Cat Populations
description: Experts say that since the overpopulation of both affects native wildlife similarly, the country should use the same strategies in managing them.
content: No amount of gentle coaxing, regimented training, rehabilitation or punishment could ever prompt cats to ignore their killer instincts. Like their feral counterparts, even the most domesticated felines threaten any potential prey they find.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Settles Discrimination Suit With Former Factory Worker
description: The carmaker and energy company settled with a Black man who had worked at its California factory and had won a $3 million judgment against the company.
content: Tesla and a former employee have agreed to settle a closely watched lawsuit that cast a harsh light on the carmaker’s treatment of Black workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘The Notebook’ Review: A Musical Tear-Jerker or Just All Wet?
description: The 2004 weepie comes to Broadway with songs by Ingrid Michaelson and a $5 box of tissues.
content: Romantic musicals are as personal as romance itself. What makes you sigh and weep may leave the person next to you bored and stony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York City to Impose Stricter Limits on Migrant Adults in Shelters
description: A legal agreement scales back the longstanding requirement that the city provide shelter to homeless people who seek it. Families will not be affected.
content: New York’s longstanding legal obligation to provide shelter to homeless people will be scaled back significantly under an agreement announced on Friday amid the city’s continuing struggle to house thousands of migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: U.S. and Allies Warn Iran Not to Send Missiles to Russia
description: The Group of 7 major industrial powers threatened “significant measures” against Tehran if it aids Moscow’s war against Ukraine, including a cutoff of Iran Air flights to Europe.
content: The United States and six other major world powers warned Iran on Friday not to provide ballistic missiles to Russia to aid Moscow’s war against Ukraine and threatened to retaliate if it does by cutting off Iranian air travel to Europe, among other measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: First Ship Carrying Food Aid Arrives in Gaza
description: The ship, the Open Arms, carried some 200 metric tons of rice, flour and other food from Cyprus. It is seen as a pilot effort for a new maritime aid corridor.
content: A humanitarian aid ship arrived on Friday in Gaza for the first time since the start of the war, a first step in a fledgling maritime operation to bring more aid to hungry Palestinians as aid groups say that Israel is restricting more efficient deliveries by road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Eric Schmitt
title: Iran and U.S. Held Secret Talks on Proxy Attacks and Cease-Fire
description: Diplomats gathered in Oman in January, with the U.S. side seeking to stop attacks on Red Sea shipping and American bases, and Iran looking for a Gaza cease-fire.
content: Iran and the United States held secret, indirect talks in Oman in January, addressing the escalating threat posed to Red Sea shipping by the Houthis in Yemen, as well as the attacks on American bases by Iran-backed militias in Iraq, according to Iranian and U.S. officials familiar with the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Uber and Lyft Threaten to Pull Out of Minneapolis After City Council Vote
description: Local lawmakers in the Minnesota city voted on Thursday to guarantee a minimum hourly wage to ride-hailing drivers.
content: Uber and Lyft are threatening to pull out of Minneapolis after a City Council vote there guaranteed a minimum hourly wage to drivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dorie Ladner, Unheralded Civil Rights Heroine, Dies at 81
description: She risked arrest and worse in pursuit of her goals of integration and voting rights from the time she was a teenager.
content: Dorie Ann Ladner, a largely unsung heroine on the front lines of the 1960s civil rights movement in the South, a crusade that shamed the nation into abolishing some of the last vestiges of legal segregation, died on Monday in Washington. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Lee
title: ‘Rear Window’ Redux, With a Blind Girl Twist
description: In Armando Lucas Correa’s thriller “The Silence in Her Eyes,” vision impairment only enhances a young woman’s sense of neighborly discord — and danger is in the air.
content: “Here comes the little blind girl,” people say when Leah walks by. But she’s not a little girl, even if she often acts like one — she’s 28 years old, and rich, the owner of a handsome apartment in Morningside Heights. Nor is she blind, really. Leah, the protagonist of “The Silence in Her Eyes,” a thriller by Armando Lucas Correa, has akinetopsia, an inability to perceive objects in motion. To her, the world appears as a string of pictures, frozen and fragmented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Gregor
title: $1.5 Million Homes in Paris
description: An industrial loft in La Villette, a former workshop in Sainte-Avoye and an updated apartment with 19-century touches on Île Saint-Louis.
content: This two-bedroom loft is in the vibrant La Villette district, formerly a neighborhood of slaughterhouses in northeast Paris that has been undergoing redevelopment since the 1980s. The 136-acre La Villette Park, with concert halls, museums, theaters, event spaces and other cultural venues, is less than 10 minutes away on foot. A comparable walk in the other direction arrives at the Bassin de la Villette, the largest artificial lake in Paris, and a bohemian area offering shops, restaurants and bars, boating and other attractions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the Lake Michigan Truther
description: His wife finds it offensive that he says it should also be considered part of Lake Huron.
content: Caroline writes: My husband insists that Lake Michigan and Lake Huron are the same lake and that it should be called “Lake Huron.” I find this offensive. I love Lake Michigan. I grew up nearby and spent many glorious summer days at the beach. Please order him to drop this and admit that Lake Michigan exists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: What a Breast Cancer Risk Calculator Can and Can’t Tell You
description: The actress Olivia Munn credited a simple tool with helping her doctor catch the disease early. But experts cautioned that it can’t give you the full picture.
content: This week, the actress Olivia Munn shared that she was diagnosed with and treated for breast cancer last year, and credited a risk calculator with helping her doctor catch the cancer early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stella Bugbee
title: Who Loves Fashion More Than a Vintage Clothing Buff?
description: Laverne Cox, Anna Sui and other enthusiasts shop at the Sturbridge Show, a gold mine for people who buy and wear exquisite old things.
content: Few people on earth put more thought, care or flair into their outfits than the aficionados at a rare vintage clothing sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Joe Camp, Filmmaker Behind ‘Benji’ Franchise, Dies at 84
description: He defied the odds to turn “Benji,” a live-action film series from a dog’s perspective, into a smash hit, and turned the film industry on its head in the process.
content: Joe Camp, a pioneering filmmaker who created the groundbreaking “Benji” franchise, which brought a lovable dog in a live-action film to the masses and became a smash success, died on Friday at his home in Bell Buckle, Tenn. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: AMC Theaters, Looking for Movies, Turns to Blumhouse
description: The theater chain and the entertainment company are teaming up for a five-day festival of old horror films in 40 cities, compensating for a lack of new films.
content: For five days starting on March 29, people who buy tickets to certain movies at certain AMC Theaters will see video messages starring … Jason Blum?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The American Society of Magical Negroes’ Review: Lampooning an Offensive Cliché
description: Kobi Libii’s satirical comedy, starring Justice Smith, tries to explore the trope but leans too hard on the conventions of superhero tales and rom-coms.
content: Kobi Libii’s satirical comedy, “The American Society of Magical Negroes,” opens in an art gallery where people are milling about. A young Black man tries to walk through the crowd, constantly apologizing and sidestepping the gallery-goers. He acts as if he feels in the way and out of place. But as we learn when he arrives at his own yarn installation, he’s one of the artists whose work is for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Trump’s Court Delays Pile Up, and Schumer Says Netanyahu ‘Lost His Way’
description: Plus, the chaos in college financial aid.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiuko Notoya and Alan Yuhas
title: A Potentially Hazardous Cat Puts a Japanese City on Alert
description: The animal fell into a tank of chemicals at a plating factory in Fukuyama and then wandered off into the night.
content: The first signs of an intruder at the metal-plating factory were footprints, ocher-tinged and varying in number of toes. A review of security footage confirmed the security breach, and the authorities quickly issued a public alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Richard Silvestri delivers a doozy of a challenge.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — This is not a puzzle to zip through unless you’re an absolute whiz at cryptics. I mulled it over for a couple of days before being able to finish. I found the southwest corner particularly tricky. Richard Silvestri, today’s constructor, is a veteran of these puzzles — this is his 51st cryptic crossword for The New York Times — and they are never easy. Some of them, however, are more of a walk in the park than this cliff-scaling expedition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: A Thirst for the Irish
description: Barry Keoghan, Paul Mescal and Cillian Murphy are among a crop of Irish hunks who have infused popular culture with big Irish energy.
content: Sabrina Carpenter may already be dating an Irish hunk: The actress and singer attended the Vanity Fair Oscars party with the Irish actor Barry Keoghan last Sunday, adding fuel to rumors of their romantic involvement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: ‘Welcome to Hell’: U.N. Panel Says Russian War Crimes Are Widespread
description: In a report headed to the Human Rights Council in Geneva next week, an investigative commission outlines the ongoing torture and starvation of Ukrainian prisoners.
content: Two years after Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, United Nations investigators say they have uncovered new evidence of systematic and widespread torture of Ukrainian prisoners held by Russian security forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Judge Rules D.A. Can Stay on Trump Georgia Case With Ex-Boyfriend Stepping Down
description: The highly anticipated ruling cut a middle path between removing Fani T. Willis for a conflict of interest and her full vindication.
content: An Atlanta judge ruled on Friday that Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, could continue leading the election interference prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump and his allies in Georgia, but only if her former romantic partner, Nathan J. Wade, withdrew from the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: What We Know About the Relationship Between the Trump Prosecutors
description: Defense lawyers accused Fani Willis of “self-dealing” by hiring Nathan Wade to manage the Trump prosecution, then going on vacations with him that he paid for, at least in part.
content: The allegations of a romance between Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, and Nathan J. Wade first emerged in a January filing by Ashleigh Merchant, a lawyer for Michael Roman, one of former President Donald J. Trump’s co-defendants in Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Who Is Ashleigh Merchant, the Lawyer Who Led the Effort to Oust Fani Willis?
description: Her revelation of a romantic relationship between the lead prosecutors in the Trump case threw the proceedings into turmoil.
content: Ashleigh Merchant, an Atlanta lawyer representing one of Donald J. Trump’s co-defendants, claimed “vindication” on Friday for her efforts to have Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, tossed off the Georgia election interference case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell
title: A French Castle Filled With a Collector’s Treasures
description: The art and antiques dealer Yves Gastou was passionate about objects and their stories. His home in Biarritz overflowed with both.
content: When the French gallerist Yves Gastou bought the Ermitage de Douce-amie — or refuge of a sweet friend — a follylike crenelated castle on the outskirts of Biarritz in southwest France, in 1990, it had the air of a place frozen in time. Hidden within a forest of bamboo and pine, bay and oak trees, the 5,380-square-foot house was built in 1900 as a retirement home for a member of the imperial court of Napoleon III, or so Gastou believed. The house had changed hands only a few times since: The woman from whom he purchased it was among the last ladies in Biarritz to travel by horse and cart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Netanyahu calls Hamas’s demands ‘ludicrous’ and proceeds with plans for a ground invasion in Rafah.
description: The Israeli prime minister rejected the latest cease-fire deal proposed by Hamas, but signaled he was open to more talks.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Friday rejected the latest cease-fire deal proposed by Hamas, calling its demands “ludicrous,” and said Israel would move forward with plans for a ground offensive in Rafah, the southern Gazan city where more than half the enclave’s population is sheltering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Emily Kask
title: In Louisiana, Extreme Weather Does the Unforgivable: Endanger Crawfish Season
description: Drought conditions over the summer boiled crawfish before farmers could harvest them, creating a dire situation that the governor has declared a disaster.
content: Adlar Stelly is 42 years old, which means it is fair to say that he has been involved in farming crawfish in Louisiana for just shy of 42 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Takeaways From the Ruling on Georgia Trump Prosecutor’s Conduct
description: Fani Willis faces an unusual decision after the much-anticipated ruling on whether she should be disqualified for having had a romantic relationship with a subordinate.
content: The much-anticipated ruling on whether Fani T. Willis should be disqualified from prosecuting former President Donald J. Trump and 14 of his allies in Georgia came on Friday, requiring her to make an unusual decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Cavanagh
title: Flower Arrangements Are Reaching New Heights
description: Floral designers are finding drama in tall, statuesque compositions.
content: “I have so much admiration for florists who can make haphazard, wild arrangements,” says Miguel Yatco, 30, the floral artist behind the Brooklyn-based studio Agos Muni. “But it’s different to how I approach things: I’m rigorous.” The compositions he produces for his fashion and design world clients — a column of billowy cream-and-orange poppies for the French fashion house Hermès; a three-foot-high mass of deep purple hydrangeas and clematis for the New York design gallery Jacqueline Sullivan — are often so tall and tightly packed that they resemble inverted cumulonimbus clouds. “I love to create the feeling of the flower floating and defying gravity,” says the designer, who likes to begin with a vessel, often a silver pedestal bowl or oversize pewter julep cup, then adds blooms to double or triple its height.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Minho Kim
title: After R.B.G. Awards Go to Musk and Murdoch, Justice Ginsburg’s Family Objects
description: The children of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who championed liberal causes and women’s rights, said the choice of recipients this year was an “affront” to the memory of their mother.
content: When Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a champion of liberal causes whose advocacy of women’s rights catapulted her to pop culture fame, helped establish a leadership award in 2019, she said she intended to celebrate “women who exemplify human qualities of empathy and humility.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How a Tiny Arts Center Is Helping a Rural County Heal After Wildfires
description: The Middletown Art Center in Lake County has turned into a “focal point for the area’s resilience and growth,” one resident said.
content: Just north of Napa Valley, famous for its picture-perfect wineries and inviting restaurants, is a California county with a far less flattering reputation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: It Was Enough to Make You Wish You Lived in a Boxcar
description: Gertrude Chandler Warner’s “The Boxcar Children,” celebrating its 100th year, depicts the delights of concocting scrumptious meals.
content: It was the food. It was always about the food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Narrowly Interprets Landmark Reduced Sentencing Law
description: The justices sided with the government in a case focused on who is eligible for shorter prison sentences under the bipartisan First Step Act passed in 2018.
content: The Supreme Court sided with the government on Friday, narrowly interpreting a provision of a landmark criminal justice law in a decision likely to limit the number of federal prisoners who are eligible for reduced sentences for nonviolent drug crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: This Treasure Hunter’s Latest Find? A 1,000-Year-Old Viking Sword.
description: Trevor Penny was magnet fishing in an English waterway near Oxford when he pulled out a rusty sword. Experts say it’s a Viking sword that is probably more than 1,000 years old.
content: The long, thin piece of metal looked like a scaffolding pole when Trevor Penny saw it on the banks of an English river last November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Serge Raoul, Whose SoHo Bistro Glittered With Stars, Dies at 86
description: Raoul’s, which he founded, was a celebrity magnet and a neighborhood institution in the 1970s and ’80s. But he had never planned on a life in the restaurant business.
content: Serge Raoul, an Alsatian-born former filmmaker who with his brother, Guy, a classically trained chef, founded Raoul’s, a clubby French bistro and SoHo canteen in Lower Manhattan that drew generations of artists, rock stars, writers, models, machers and movie people — along with those who yearned to be near them — died on March 8 at his home in Nyack, N.Y. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: A Prosecutor in the Trump Georgia Case Resigns
description: Also, a jolt to the housing market.
content: Nathan Wade resigned today from his post as special prosecutor in the Georgia election interference case against Donald Trump. The move came after an Atlanta judge told Fani Willis, Wade’s boss and former romantic partner, that she and her office could keep the case only if Wade stepped down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Tina Antolini, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell and Jon Pareles
title: Kacey Musgraves Finds Inner Peace on Her New Album
description: Our music critic reviews “Deeper Well.”
content: Our chief pop music critic, Jon Pareles, says Kacey Musgraves’s fifth album of original songs, “Deeper Well,” finds the artist ready to place the youthful mistakes of her past behind her for a quieter, more contented sound. He describes the new songs as “pared down and understated,” and says they are “about finding wonder and gratitude in personal connections and in nature.” Here are some of his favorite tracks from the album.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russian Missile Strikes Kill at Least 20 in Odesa, Ukraine Says
description: Two missiles hit the same spot, Ukrainian authorities said, killing some rescuers who had responded to the first attack.
content: A Russian missile attack on Odesa killed at least 20 people and injured 73 others, Ukrainian authorities said on Friday, the latest in a series of deadly air assaults on the southern Ukrainian port city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul and Rebecca Smeyne
title: At These New York Art World Parties, Everyone’s a Critic
description: Guests like Darren Aronofsky, David Byrne and Huma Abedin channeled their inner Jerry Saltz at two of this season’s major events.
content: As the sun set in Manhattan’s meatpacking district on Monday evening, the Whitney Museum of American Art swelled with crowds for the opening of the 81st Whitney Biennial. This year’s show, “Even Better Than the Real Thing,” contends with questions of what is “real” through works about the rise of artificial intelligence, the fluidity of gender and the fragility of nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Amid Israeli Restrictions, First Friday of Ramadan Sees Little Unrest at Al Aqsa Mosque
description: A heavy Israeli police contingent checked worshipers outside the holy site, after Hamas called for an “escalation” from Palestinians in response to the war in Gaza.
content: A heavy Israeli police contingent checked worshipers on Friday entering the Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem, where the threat of unrest loomed over the end of the first week of Ramadan, the holiest month for Muslims and one that has taken on added significance during the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: What do you do if you hate both Biden and Trump?
description: It’s the election of our discontent.
content: Many voters from both parties are less than enthusiastic about their likely options this November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Doug Blevins, Kicking Guru for College and N.F.L. Players, Dies at 60
description: He fine-tuned the mechanics of punters and kickers, including Adam Vinatieri, the N.F.L.’s career scoring leader, even as he lived with cerebral palsy.
content: Doug Blevins, who successfully coached college and N.F.L. kickers like Adam Vinatieri and Justin Tucker, despite never having played football because he had cerebral palsy, died on Sunday in Johnson City, in east Tennessee. He was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé and Maansi Srivastava
title: Fixing Central Park’s Bumpy Sidewalks
description: A 108-block sidewalk restoration project led by the Central Park Conservancy balances historical aesthetics with modern needs.
content: The sidewalks surrounding Central Park were designed to help you escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin and Siyi Zhao
title: What China Is Saying About the TikTok Furor in Washington
description: A bill to force TikTok’s sale in the United States has been criticized by Beijing but has not triggered a high-alert public response or retaliation.
content: This is not the first time that China has seen a frenzy over TikTok consume Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Roger Cohen
title: Macron and Scholz Meet, Looking to Patch Up Differences on Ukraine
description: The leaders of France and Germany tried to heal an increasingly public rift over their approach to the war, holding talks alongside Poland’s prime minister on support for Kyiv.
content: Chancellor Olaf Scholz and President Emmanuel Macron of France met in Berlin on Friday looking to smooth over their differences on how to support Ukraine in its war with Russia and allay concerns that the Franco-German “engine of Europe” is sputtering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: 5 Cases When Parents Were Convicted After a Shooting by Their Child
description: The mother and father of a Michigan teenager who carried out a school shooting are among the parents who have been convicted of crimes in the aftermath.
content: A jury on Thursday found James Crumbley partially responsible for the deadliest school shooting in Michigan’s history. Mr. Crumbley’s son, Ethan, killed four people and injured seven more at Oxford High School in suburban Detroit on Nov. 30, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Court Temporarily Halts S.E.C.’s New Climate Rules
description: Two fracking companies had challenged requirements that some businesses disclose more information about the risks they face from climate change.
content: A federal court on Friday temporarily halted new rules from the Securities Exchange Commission that require public companies to disclose more about the business risks they face from climate change, siding with two oil and gas companies that criticized the requirements as costly and arbitrary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Sheriff Had Cause to Take Maine Gunman Into Custody Before Shootings
description: An interim report from a commission investigating the mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, found that the gunman’s weapons could and should have been removed.
content: A commission investigating the mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, concluded on Friday that local law enforcement officers should have taken the gunman into custody and seized his weapons before he killed 18 people on Oct. 25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Who Has the Secret to Well-Being? The Answer May Surprise You.
description: Toddlers — full of energy, curiosity and laughter — have a lot to teach adults, experts say.
content: When it comes to happiness and living well, we can learn a lot from toddlers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Masters of the Air’ Review: Hanks and Spielberg, Back at War
description: The team behind “Band of Brothers” and “The Pacific” returns to World War II and the Greatest Generation, this time piloting B-17 bombers.
content: This review contains spoilers for the entire season of “Masters of the Air.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: 4 Ways a Settlement Could Change the Housing Industry
description: The influential National Association of Realtors agreed to make several changes to its policies to settle class-action lawsuits brought by home sellers who say they were forced to pay inflated commissions to real estate agents.
content: In the early hours of Friday morning, the National Association of Realtors agreed to a global settlement deal that would resolve several lawsuits against the trade group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Wife Plans to End Her Life. Should I Tell My Very Religious Father?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to disclose a delicate decision to a loved one who may oppose it.
content: In a few weeks, my wife will have an accompanied suicide. Her daily pain and increasing loss of function led her to this difficult decision, after more than 25 years of battling multiple sclerosis. We’ve recently started telling friends and family about what’s coming, which has been an incredibly hard and yet beautiful process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Why a Native American Nation Is Challenging the U.S. Over a 1794 Treaty
description: The Onondaga have asked an international commission to find that the United States violated a treaty guaranteeing the nation 2.5 million acres of land.
content: Four or five years ago, Sidney Hill’s young son came to him with a question that Mr. Hill didn’t know how to answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Shabab Gunmen Penetrate Heavy Security to Besiege Hotel in Somalia
description: The attack in the capital, which left three dead and 27 injured, points to Al Shabab’s ability to continue terrorizing the country, despite a Somali government offensive and American airstrikes.
content: Five assailants with the terrorist group Al Shabab stormed a hotel in a highly fortified area close to Somalia’s presidential palace on Thursday night, engaging security forces for about 12 hours in sustained fighting that left three people dead and injured 27 — including members of parliament — before the militants were finally killed, according to Somali officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davit Giorgadze and Kk Obi
title: The Many Textures of Spring Fashion
description: From woolly tweeds to smooth silk, tactile fabrics make for a highly sensational season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Adam Rasgon
title: New Palestinian Prime Minister Offers Little Hope for Change
description: Muhammad Mustafa has long been an adviser to President Mahmoud Abbas. Critics are skeptical he can produce the “revitalized Palestinian Authority” that Washington wants.
content: The appointment on Thursday of Muhammad Mustafa as the new prime minister of the Palestinian Authority was supposed to be a nod to international demands for a more technocratic and less corrupt administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Thomas Adès Takes a Step Toward the Classical Music Canon
description: As Adès premieres an orchestral work, “The Exterminating Angel” is receiving something rare in contemporary opera: a new production.
content: Pity living composers, toiling away in a field that has long favored dead ones. If they get a precious commission, the cycle tends to go something like this: The work premieres, and then travels to any other ensemble or company that helped to pay for it. After that, who knows. The fate of contemporary music typically comes down to marketability — hits still exist! — and to that strange, slippery thing called legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Mainstream G.O.P. Group to Target Bob Good as It Shifts Mission and Members
description: An organization founded to support Republican moderates is taking aim at the Virginia lawmaker and backing a different hard-right candidate who aligns with its new focus: purging Congress of G.O.P. rebels.
content: The Republican Main Street Partnership, a group that supports center-leaning House Republicans, plans to direct half a million dollars into a bid to defeat Representative Bob Good, a hard-right lawmaker from Virginia, making an unusual push to oust a sitting Republican member of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robbie Spencer
title: The Proposal Expert Gets Her Own Surprise Ring
description: Ben Cohen wanted to make sure Lexi Tobin, a wedding influencer and proposal planner, got the proposal of a lifetime.
content: Benjamin Ryan Cohen can easily recall how he met Lexi Brooke Tobin because it was on his 31st birthday, June 18, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Kushner Developing Deals Overseas Even as His Father-in-Law Runs for President
description: Donald Trump’s son-in-law, who was also a senior White House official, said he was close to finalizing real estate projects in Albania and Serbia.
content: Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of Donald J. Trump, confirmed on Friday that he was closing in on major real estate deals in Albania and Serbia, the latest example of the former president’s family doing business abroad even as Mr. Trump seeks to return to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: What Groups Need Affirmative Action?

content: In June, my husband and I found out we were pregnant. It would become the third baby we would lose in the last two years. I call her a baby although I know she was an embryo, her heartbeat stilled at six weeks and two days. I call her a baby because I can feel her weight on my chest and see her eyelashes in my mind. I call her a baby to honor the grief of those who have lost babies that existed only in our bodies and minds. Our babies that existed as dreams and then as memories.
